description: Borrowed from Latin convenientia, from conveniens (“suitable”), present participle of convenire (“to come together, suit”). Doublet of convenance.

examples: Fast food is popular because of its cost and convenience.

entries.meaning: Any object that makes life more convenient; a helpful item.

examples: We will come over and begin the work at your convenience.

entries.meaning: (chiefly Britain) Ellipsis of public convenience: a public lavatory.

verbs.description: convenience (third-person singular simple present conveniences, present participle conveniencing, simple past and past participle convenienced)

examples: These are equally viable times and I propose we alternate between the two times in order to convenience as many people as possible.
